title: Outrage after Northumberland cottage covered in Islamophobic graffiti
text:
Outrage after Northumberland cottage covered in Islamophobic graffiti 13:34, 12 Jul 2016 The cottage in Allerburn Lea, Alnwick, was vandalised with the graffiti and council workers were quick to get it removed Shares Get daily news by email Vile anti-islam graffiti on a cottage in Allerbrn Lea in Alnwick 
Islamophobic graffiti and swastikas has been sprayed all over a quaint little cottage in Alnwick . 
The words ‘Death to Islam’ and other disgusting vandalism were discovered daubed over the property on Tuesday morning. 
Police were at the scene investigating and Northumberland County Council workers have now removed the paint from the former caretakers’ cottage. 
The cottage, which sits at the entrance to the Allerburn Lea estate, currently sits empty, with no one living at the property. 
It is believed to have been vandalised overnight. 
The yob painted left-facing swastikas, commonly used in Buddhism, rather than the icon adopted by the Nazis prior to World War II. 
Alnwick councillor Gordon Castle condemned the “truly depressing” act, saying that it’s the first time he’d seen such a disgusting crime in the area. 
He said: “It most definitely does not reflect Alnwick, It’s something the likes of which I have never seen here before. 
“If there are these sorts of views in Alnwick, they’ve been extremely well hidden. 
“I hope it’s just a mindless youth yob, who didn’t know what they’re doing, but if it’s someone who knew the full extent of their horrible intentions, they deserve to be dealt with.” 
Alnwick resident Claire Barber who also owns a business in the town said “I have lived and worked in Alnwick for almost 17 years with my daughters and it is a very peaceful town with an exceptionally low crime rate, so to see the grafitti this morning was a real shock. 
“The former Northumberland County Council lodge is well known and is located right at the entrance to Allerburn Lea housing estate, where families and executives primarily live. 
“Thankfully the police and the council were quick off the mark to clean it off. 
“We need to maintain the town’s reputation as one of the nicest places to live in the UK”. 
Confirming that it had been reported to the council to be cleaned off, Coun Castle said: “It would be easy to link this to Brexit, but I would like to think that this wasn’t a result of the referendum. 
“We’ve seen across the country an increase in hate crime, I hope this is not part of that, but you must not rule it out. 
“I’m prepared for the worst and hope for the best.”
